We remain optimistic on the future of Web3/crypto and we look forward to continuing to play a key role in building that future together with brilliant teams.

We hope the thread shows a clearer picture of how we think and work as a VC and elucidates the nuance behind exiting an investment. 

Labeling any investor as "dumpoor" based on a single action paints a very incomplete picture and frankly just shows how ignorant one can be.

We have never recommended/‚Äôshilled‚Äô any projects that we are no longer bullish on for exit liquidity. In fact, we have encouraged many of our portco to lower their public sale valuations to be on a similar level as the last private round to reward early retail participants.
We evaluate deals primarily on fundamental merits (team, tech, product, valuation, TAM etc), and not based on how early we got in / how fast can we exit.

4) Fundamentals of project deteriorated, eg. #1 Lack of product-market fit / eg. #2 Team stopped building or mismanaged the project

And this is extremely common in the startup world, being in crypto/web 3 doesn't magically increase the success rate of running a startup.

However, difficult decisions have to be made when the following occur:

3) Thesis invalidated. Eg. vertical is proven as unviable

Does this mean we never ever sell?

No.

We always invest with the intention and hope that our theses will be validated, and the tokens will accrue long-term value for us to keep holding.

That said, we constantly adapt our theses by actively monitoring the fundamentals.
We do not sell unlocked tokens just because of market conditions, as long as we believe our thesis is still intact and the investments still have a high chance of delivering in the future.

There are many assets where we diamond-handed from peak to trough drawdown of more than 90% despite the expiry of lock-up - examples include, but are not limited to, $AAVE, $JOE, $LDO, $BNT, $MC. We work with the teams closely and actively participate in governance.

At DeFiance, our guiding principle to investing is to combine fundamental theses with an active involvement approach. As such, our default stance is to hold our investments post-liquidity event and actively engage with teams as long as the initial theses remain intact.
2) Being up-to-date with industry/market trends ‚Äî Refine our theses and market view, and allocate capital + time in the most appropriate areas.

First, an overview of what we believe are the key responsibilities of a VC

1) Commitment to portfolio investments‚Äî Engage with the team to help them achieve product-market fit and growth. Ultimately, our success as a firm depends heavily on the success of our portfolio companies

The public‚Äôs view on Web3/Crypto VCs is getting increasingly polarized. CT always speaks of the archetypal evil VC, but the reality is often more nuanced. Just gonna lay out our approach to exiting investments to clear all these doubts once and for all

23/ I also want to commend the rational skeptic that are willing to stick their neck out,bear the mob's rage to call out the whole event: @Galois_Capital especially for risking his industry reputation, and all the other major influencers that been warning about the risk. GJ!

23/ I'm more cognizant of the influence we have in shaping the outcome and public perception of this space. 

This quote will be taken to heart https://t.co/CEYkuxvkyB

22/ We were too liberal and accepting to many unacceptable behaviour and actions, towards our portfolio teams, industry associates, important leaders. 

Going forward, we will only invest in teams/projects where we can morally give them our full support.

21/ Personally this has been an incredibly humbling and difficult event. We generally got the bearish direction right so been a lot more cautious but many of our assumptions are challenged and invalidated.

We could have done much more as well to prevent this.

20/ A reputable, independent  and well managed DeFi directory with a comprehensive disclosure framework make sense and should do a lot to alleviate the knowledge gap. E.g. @MessariCrypto disclosure registry is but more detailed. Probably it can be spin-off as a crypto public good

19/ I think a more comprehensive disclosure framework for DeFi should be championed so instead of a forced KYC/AML nightmare like the tradfi world, we should push for maximum awareness/education before encouraging the usage/acess of DeFi.

18/ That said crypto is the freest market in the world so such actors will always appear and it is up to the ourselves to be more critical and scrutinizing to prevent such events from ever happening again.

We need to be more professional!

17/ This event will no doubt set the space back by a few years and attract increased & justified scrutiny from authorities and regulators alike. We need to do better than now to show that this space is worth supporting and advocate for.

16/ I highly recommend this book to understand the history of VC and the role VC played in shaping tech industry 

https://t.co/xQLH0Ad8QG

15/ This role is well understood in non Web 3 VC world granted even some of them have succumbed to market pressure given competition from other kind of investors such as Tiger/Softbank

This has lead to some major debacle such as WeWork that dented VC's reputation in public

14/ As the space grow exponentially, Web 3/Crypto VC's role as function of public signal become increasingly important amidst lack of common standards public can use to evaluate the legitimacy of Web 3 projects. We all need to hold ourselves to higher standard.

13/ While I generally refrain from such behaviour, I did nothing to call out and advised against some of my friends/ industry associates from behaving in such manner. I'm also partially swayed and accustomed to such behaviour after a while.

Quote below rings even louder now. https://t.co/qlITLi5oLJ

12/ "Your opinion/views are worthless/wrong because I've been proven right in the past and I'm way more successful and/or richer than you" become a common argument type used by many in our space forgetting that they are nobody just few years ago as well.

11/ Somewhere along the journey, many of us lost our way and I've lost a lot of respect for people I used to held in high regard. Rigourous debate backed by substantial research & analysis are frown upon but instead lazy ad hominem refutation are used to shut down skepticism.

The deference to the "smartest guy in the room" and hubris of the leader and community in face of reasonable skepticism & criticism contributed significantly to the downfall of Terra. No one is above the market and the downfall hubris can bring is once again demonstrated.

10/ However the fragility of such design was once again exposed amidst a weak market environment. 

We significantly underestimated how powerless the smartest & most capable group of people can be in a hostile environment when the natural physics and fundamentals are against you

- UST supply increase/decrease at more gradual rate
- wider non reflexive/mainstream usecase of UST such as payment
- large community (especially in Asia)

The end game is not just UST success, but a succesful crypto native stablecoin back by a sovereign blockchain network.

9/ Terra ecosystem also have one of the best UI/UX and developers talents and is the leading protocol built using Cosmos SDK.

With creation of LFG, we think decent chance Terra model can thrive with:
- partial collateralized model (BTC backing) 
- Anchor yield adjustment

8/ I been a long-time skeptic of algo-stablecoins and likewise Terra since 2018 due to the inherent fragility in such design.

However Terra's success in 2021 have challenged my view and we seen a wide group of legitimate& respected people supporting Terra (Jump/Delphi/Hashed)

7/ DeFiance had the opportunity to invest in many highly contested L1 treasury OTC deals but passed most of them even when the alt L1 narrative was popular. Instead we continue to focus on DeFi and been selective in our backing.

6/ While we continue to support DeFi on Ethereum, we recognise there is genuine demand for DeFi built on other chains. But we don't adopt an EV based approach in investing and only invest on projects built on chains that we think the ecosystem will thrive over long-term.

5/ But the market have definitely make us more open-minded on how a project can be built and bootstrap successfully via different ways. Afterall we were proven wrong as a skeptic on many teams/projects numerous times already. (Cope is real)

4/ We are often ridiculed for missing out on "DeFi 2.0" as a DeFi focused investor. Market as a whole generally reward such risk taking opportunities. This led to multiple discussions, research and debate internally on what is real/sustainable, what is unsustaimable "narrative"

3/ As bull market go on, more participants chase the higher risk opportunities and many are even proud of their high degen score. Some have lead to spectacular gain and narrative of DeFi 2.0 replacing the 1.0 become widly popular.

2/ Many foundational DeFi protocols that were built during the 18/19 bear market emerge and thrive this cycle, become the core financial primitive to build on top. They continue to prioritize security, protocol risk management but also become less fun and degen to speculate & use

Some personal thoughts/reflection on the recent event.

1/ As an early DeFi participant& advocate, I always believe that a decentralized money and network NEED a decentralized financial stack to support it. 

Else we will just be moving crypto between centralized custodian.

19/ Trust the browser and not the website. Any content below the browser bar should be deemed insecure and can be a potential attack vector. Some DApp may pop up a window to ask you to login into your crypto extension wallet if you are not logged in. Do not type your password in.
18/ Improve phishing and spam email detection by properly configuring your DNS setting for your email. Use hard fail or strict mode where possible for SPF, DKIM and DMARC

17/ Regular cyber security training for team members: All team members should be required to go through cyber security training for their on-boarding, this is something that tends to be neglected as the organization grows.

16/ Implement an address monitoring system: Internal crypto wallet addresses should be monitored closely so that when unauthorized transactions happen, the team can be made aware immediately and take action as soon as possible. Both Etherscan and Nansen have such solutions.

14/ Bookmark your commonly used crypto DApp website. From time to time, phishing websites are being served out by search engine apps. If not careful during the search, you may end up accessing a phishing site. It will be better to access them through your bookmark list.
13/ whenever possible a hardware 2FA like YubiKey should be used. Apply to both company and personal accounts.

12/ Implement 2FA for all sign-in: This is non-crypto specific but is important enough to warrant a mention. Cloud storage, Emails, Messaging apps like Telegram should all have 2FA for logins, do not use SMS 2FA and use Google authenticator instead,

11/ Dedicated computers for crypto transactions. There should be dedicated computers only for engaging in crypto transactions that do not interact with any emails, internet link, messaging apps, opening MS words documents, PDF etc.

10/ We have heard of this case from one of our portfolio companies where applicants for their software engineer role appear to be suspicious in interview, and unable to match up with their profile in their resume.

9/ Exercise extra due diligence in hiring remote teams especially software engineers/developers: ‚ÄúThe Lazarus APT group has even engaged in the creation of fake companies for the development of cryptocurrency software."

8/ At the very least it should be a multi-signature wallet like Gnosis Safe secured by a few hardware wallets. I highly recommend going for the next level of custody solution like Fireblocks, Copper, Qredo etc. As they come with native multisig 2FA for transaction approval.

7/ Storing on-chain cryptoassets on enterprise grade custody solution: An EOA secured by one hardware wallet is insufficient as they can insert a false Metamask browser extension leading to approval of unintended transactions.

5/ Once the current attack method gets less effective, such as a trojanized DeFi App and Wallet attack discovered lately. Given the success, it is likely North Korea will dedicate more resources to this group to scale up the intensity of the attack.

https://t.co/uogzBha4BB

13/ We know that currently, very few sizeable investors use this approach when it come to public market in crypto.

Without more market participants like this, insane market volatility will continue in crypto until this changes.

12/ At DeFiance we always practice more of a stock picker mentality when it come to public market and generally focus on allocating capital to the projects/protocols with good fundamentals that we think deserves it to make the market more efficient.
11/ So almost inevitably, all VCs exit becomes dumping on retails until we  have a newer crop of institutional market participants that are active in the crypto public market.

10/ Without mutual/passive funds in public market, the buying pressure of all VC unlocked bags almost 100% go to retails, with occasional trading in and out by the crypto hedge funds and prop trading firms.

However as we have seen, retails come and go with the market condition.

9/ However currently, this category of market participants is almost non-existent, the closet we get to is @BitwiseInvest but they are still at early stage.

Crypto skipped a crucial step in the public market formation.

Compare to retails, they also have a more rigourous investment process. 

This lead to more efficient capital allocation, which means more demand for good fundamental asset and less for vapourware who generally prey on retails' ignorance.

This also helps to smoothen volatility.

8/ The major difference between mutual/passive index funds and VC is they are major participants in the public market by virtue of mandate, and unlikey hedge funds wont sell everything to get out with a hint of market stress.

7/ In traditional market, it started with retails and gradually dominated by mutual funds and passive index funds. Hedge funds and VCs are a much more recent thing and only command significant market power from 2000s. The investing gurus of 80s and 90s are all public stock picker

6/ This cycle we have new entrants, the fabled institutions have finally arrived. But they have not venture beyond BTC and even for BTC, their involvement are sporadic in nature and often serve a catalyst for event driven trade.

5/ Trading is also generally not their edge so buying from open market will also subject them to mark to market swings which is not comfortable to most VCs.

Even for growth stage stuff, buying from treasury at discount with lock-up is still preferred to buying from market.

4/ Crypto VC is on the extreme end. Most are chasing 100x return, generally focus on private market where their perceived edge is stronger. Its also harder to justify charging 2/20 by buying something on open market. As a result there's always an incentive to fund 'xxx' killer

3/ crypto hedge funds by and large are trading the market trend and tend to exacerbate the momentum as well. Due to their liquid nature(LP redemption), they tend not to get into a position that is hard to get out. As as result most of their positions are short-term in nature.

2/ Most retails don't do much due diligence when it comes to crypto investing(or is it punting?) as shown time and time again, lured easily to buying memecoins with low unit bias. 

Which is why we see stuff that have not deliver still trading at top 10 mcap (ADA, XRP etc).

1/ Currently there is 4 broad category of market participants in crypto: retails, crypto hedge funds, crypto VC, institutions (Microstrategy etc)

But this also means crypto have run ahead of itself in terms of market development. A key category of market participants is missing.

Most successful DeFi investors I know still keep their gains within the ecosystem and investing in new promising DeFi protocols to help the space grow to another level.

All factors above lead me to conclude that this bull market is likely to be more sustainable than the prev one

3/ Unlike ICO where the tens of million raised usually flow out from the crypto ecosystem to founders' yacht, operating expenses etc. Most of the gains made on DeFi right now stays within the crypto ecosystem.

There is minimal value leakage out now.

2/ Most active crypto investment funds now are the survivor of 2018 bear market and they are well aware of the danger of investing at inflated valuation. 

On private market side, we usually see less than $10m FDV for unlaunched and $30m-$50m for launched DeFi protocols.

Yet they are still trading at lower valuation than some of the ghost layer 1 chain like Litecoin, Cardano, Stella now, even lower when compare to their peak valuation of $10bn+.

The top DeFi crypto will continue to go up and replace these dead layer 1 chain in top 10-20 crypto.

Three reasons why this DeFi lead bull market will be more sustainable than the ICO lead bull market:

1/ Unlike ICO where most projects raised tens of millions of pure idea and empty promises, most DeFi protocols right now have product market fit and increasing tractions/usage.

Instead of liquidating a trader's entire position at one go, Deribit incrementally liquidate the position up to 12.5% of total position and stop the liquidation as soon as the margin balance is higher than maintenance margin. This protect traders against a wick if price recovers. https://t.co/3pWsFzsPFe

Additional piece of info after a chat with @DeribitExchange team:

Deribit had never had socialised losses in 3 years of operation, where we see Bitcoin go from $400 to ~$20,000 and back to low $3000, this is due to their much friendlier way of auto liquidation mechanism.

@zhusu There's clear evidence in this, most strata title commercial properties trade at discount to non-strata and developers almost exclusively build non-strata commercial properties nowadays to retain better control over tenancy mix.

So by going long the futures contracts, traders will profit from both the spot price increase + the contango widerning. Although this is not without risk, if ETH price drop from current level, futures will also drop harder than spot/perp price.

-End

In short, when ETH have a bullish price action, the contango will get wider, currently June futures are trading at 9.9% annualised premium while Sep futures premium are trading at 7.6%. When spot ETH is trading above 180 weeks ago, both premium are above 20% on annualised basis

Currently ETH forward curve are dictated by the spot ETH and stablecoin lending/borrowing rate, when market is bullish, demand to borrow ETH decrease as most traders don't want to short anymore, thus making futures position more attractive to hold than a spot position.

5/ If you're bullish on ETH, long on futures not only avoid positive funding, but also means effectively taking a long time spread position on ETH, this is the more effective way to capturing the full ETH upside should the bullish thesis materialised over the next 2 months

4/ However, the high IQ play is actually to express the long position through futures contract instead, currently there are June and Sep expiry contracts listed now. Traders don't pay funding on futures

3/ Bitmex ETHUSD perp contracts have an average of 0.27%/day positive funding rate over the last 2 week(long pay shorts), this eats into the ETH bulls' profit significantly especially on a leveraged position, this compare with @DeribitExchange where funding are much lesser

2/ Deribit ETH futures allows you to margin trade ETH perpetuals or futures contracts with ETH up to 50x leverage, this is unlike Bitmex ETHUSD quanto contracts where your margin and PnL are both BTC, adding complexity if you want to overweight ETH in your portfolio

@RyanSAdams Other platform also face centralisation and counter-party risk as well. I agree DAI demand decrease rates, I was contending the argument that Maker offers a deeply discounted loan while it is likely not due to the hidden cost of extra capital set aside+ liquidation fees.
@_backsplash yes, @sassal0x cover it a lot, in fact he was actually racing against the oracle to prevent being liquidated, I remember he was less than 10 cts away from liquidation.

@RyanSAdams Other crypto-collateralised loan have the advantage of not facing liquidation, which means that issuers don't have to set aside extra capital to top up when the underlying collateral drops in value near to 150% collateralisation ratio
@RyanSAdams https://t.co/eUGLzJZKps

4/ This is the additional cost CDP issuer have to account for when taking leverage with their ETH holdings, both mentally and operationally, therefore while on surface Maker offers a lower rate, it might actually be higher if you factor in hidden costs above.

3/ Due to the volatile $ETH price, they will need to monitor their position closely to avoid liquidation and prepare to burn DAI/lock more ETH, the past few months have shown this to be true, a big CDP holder was less than $0.1 away from being liquidated last month.

2/ Yes Maker compete against traditional collateralised loans such as Nexo but instead have its own set of trade-off. Although they offer a much lower rate, the borrowers are faced with the risk of liquidation at a hefty 13% fee unless they are extremely over-collateralised
1/ I am a big fan of Ethereum and decentralised stablecoin but I have to say this is a misleading statement. CDP on @MakerDAO is NOT a deeply discounted loan.

@RyanSAdams This is actually market-rate for a fully-collateralised loan in most developed countries, especially a loan with a 67% LTV ratio, in addition the potential liquidation fee of 13% is very significant threat and requires constant monitoring due to the volatility of ETH price.
